input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0000181', '0000181', '0000817', '0000817'], 'document_source': ['GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR'], 'document_url': ['https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/chordoma', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/chordoma', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/prekallikrein-deficiency', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/prekallikrein-deficiency'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C0008487', 'C0008487', 'C0272339', 'C0272339'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T191', 'T191', 'T047', 'T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ['CHDM|chordocarcinoma|chordoepithelioma|notochordal sarcoma|notochordoma', 'CHDM|chordocarcinoma|chordoepithelioma|notochordal sarcoma|notochordoma', 'congenital prekallikrein deficiency|Fletcher factor deficiency|Fletcher trait|PKK deficiency', 'congenital prekallikrein deficiency|Fletcher factor deficiency|Fletcher trait|PKK deficiency'], 'question_id': ['0000181-4', '0000181-5', '0000817-1', '0000817-2'], 'question_focus': ['chordoma', 'chordoma', 'prekallikrein deficiency', 'prekallikrein deficiency'], 'question_type': ['inheritance', 'treatment', 'information', 'frequency'], 'question': ['Is chordoma inherited ?', 'What are the treatments for chordoma ?', 'What is (are) prekallikrein deficiency ?', 'How many people are affected by prekallikrein deficiency ?'], 'answer': ['When development of a chordoma is associated with a duplication of the T gene inherited from a parent, one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to increase the risk of the disorder, which is an inheritance pattern called autosomal dominant. People with this duplication inherit an increased risk of this condition, not the condition itself.  Other cases of chordoma are sporadic, which means they occur in people with no history of the condition in their family.', 'These resources address the diagnosis or management of chordoma:  - Chordoma Foundation: Treatment  - Duke Spine Center  - Genetic Testing Registry: Chordoma  - Massachusetts General Hospital   These resources from MedlinePlus offer information about the diagnosis and management of various health conditions:  - Diagnostic Tests  - Drug Therapy  - Surgery and Rehabilitation  - Genetic Counseling   - Palliative Care', 'Prekallikrein deficiency is a blood condition that usually causes no health problems. In people with this condition, blood tests show a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT), a result that is typically associated with bleeding problems; however, bleeding problems generally do not occur in prekallikrein deficiency. The condition is usually discovered when blood tests are done for other reasons.  A few people with prekallikrein deficiency have experienced health problems related to blood clotting such as heart attack, stroke, a clot in the deep veins of the arms or legs (deep vein thrombosis), nosebleeds, or excessive bleeding after surgery. However, these are common problems in the general population, and most affected individuals have other risk factors for developing them, so it is unclear whether their occurrence is related to prekallikrein deficiency.', 'The prevalence of prekallikrein deficiency is unknown. Approximately 80 affected individuals in about 30 families have been described in the medical literature. Because prekallikrein deficiency usually does not cause any symptoms, researchers suspect that most people with the condition are never diagnosed.']}
